docs.lead_paragraph: HCA-the Healthcare Company owes the federal government more than $400 million for filing false cost reports to inflate payments from Medicare, the Justice Department will say in a court filing that will be made public on Friday, according to lawyers who sued HCA. The demand for repayment is part of a 1,000-page complaint from the Justice Department, said the lawyers, Stephen Meagher and Peter Chatfield, who represent private whistle-blowers working with the government on the case.

headline.main: U.S. to Seek $400 Million More at HCA

docs.abstract: Justice Department reportedly seeks more than $400 million from HCA-the Healthcare Co for filing false cost reports to inflate payments from Medicare; court filing may increase pressure on HCA to settle civil claims that it filed false cost reports with Medicare health insurance plan from 1987 to 1997 and paid doctors kickbacks to refer Medicare patients from 1988 to 1998 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than a dozen journalists have been chosen to receive the 2000 George Polk Awards for reporting on issues that included the Colombian drug trade, the operations of the Federal Aviation Administration and the safety standards for car tires. The awards in 12 categories were announced yesterday by Long Island University, which administers the prize. Those honored include John B. Oakes, a former editor at The New York Times who received a career award, and Donald L. Barlett and James B. Steele of Time magazine, who received the award for magazine reporting, their sixth Polk Award for investigative reporting as a team.

headline.main: New York Times Among Winners of Polk Awards for Journalism

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush's reversal this week on a pledge to cut power plant emissions highlights the difficulty of controlling carbon dioxide, a seemingly benign ingredient of the air people exhale, but also, many scientists say, a chief cause of global warming. A growing body of research has concluded that carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping greenhouse gases appear responsible for at least half of a warming trend over the last 50 years and pose a threat to ecosystems, water supplies, coastlines and tropical agriculture in the new century.

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of influential Republicans in the House, including three of the top party leaders, today proposed several new tax breaks that would substantially increase the cost and scope of President Bush's tax cut plan. Few if any of the new proposals are likely to become law. The Republicans' motives seemed to include giving some fresh meat to their conservative supporters, putting pressure on the Senate not to cave in to pressure from moderates, forcing Democrats into casting difficult votes and maybe even allowing President Bush to appear to be taking a middle ground.

headline.main: Republicans, In New Tactic, Offer Increase In Tax Breaks

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration told Congress today in the most explicit terms that all the payroll tax revenue flowing into the Medicare trust fund would be used exclusively for Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled. The statement came after a drumbeat of criticism from Democrats, who said President Bush was in effect planning to rob Medicare to pay for tax cuts.

headline.main: Official Vows Not to Draw On the Medicare Trust Fund

docs.abstract: Bush administration tells Congress that all payroll tax revenue flowing into Medicare trust fund would be used exclusively for Medicare; Tommy G Thompson, secretary of health and human services, testifies before House Ways and Means Committee, seeking to minimize political damage from growing perception that White House would, as Democrats contend, raid Medicare; Pres Bush, in his budget of Feb 28, suggested that surplus in Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund is part of contingency fund that could be used for future needs; nothing in president's budget earmarks money for Medicare, setting off alarms among Democrats; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE new economy is temporarily dead on Wall Street, but Washington is acting as if it did not even know it ever existed. The Republicans are setting the antediluvian tone with a tax-cut proposal and a new budget that almost completely ignore vast changes in American life the last 25 years. But the Democratic response is almost as unenlightened. It is as if we are being led by a bunch of 19th-century lawmakers. The benefits and durability of the new economy were inevitably exaggerated. If the economy of the 1990's was indeed ''new,'' America enjoyed a new economy in every generation of its history, beginning with the cotton economy after the War of 1812 and extending over the next two centuries through canals, water mills, steamships, mass retailers, steel and petroleum, railroads, electric appliances, autos and television.

headline.main: Economic Scene; Tax cuts are in the air, and both political parties have their heads in the sand.

docs.abstract: Jeff Madrick Economic Scene column says neither Republicans nor Democrats are addressing big changes in Americans life brought about by 'new economy,' including diminished job security, rise of temporary and part-time employment and self-employment, decline in percentage of workers entitled to unemployment insurance, rise in hours worked by families as result of stagnating wages and aging work force; photo (M)
